SourcedStatement: In Kansas, lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union have drafted a letter reminding election workers that a gender marker on a person’s identification does not need to match or correspond to a voter’s gender expression.
Name: American Civil Liberties Union
Justification: lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union

SourcedStatement: Staff for the organization have also held clinics elsewhere to prepare trans Americans for the identification requirements they will have to navigate.
Name: American Civil Liberties Union
Justification: Staff for the organization

SourcedStatement: In eight battleground states, the nonprofit VoteRiders is on the ground helping voters get the identification they need to cast ballots in the November election — and one that reflects who they are.
Name: VoteRiders
Justification: the nonprofit VoteRiders

SourcedStatement: Equality Florida, the state’s leading LGBTQ+ advocacy group, is holding “know your rights” trainings in the wake of new regulations barring many transgender voters from obtaining photo identification that reflects their gender.
Name: Equality Florida
Justification: the state’s leading LGBTQ+ advocacy group

SourcedStatement: Last year, Tennessee Gov. Bill Lee, a Republican, signed a bill into law that defines sex as “determined by anatomy and genetics existing at the time of birth.” The state’s Department of Safety and Homeland Security then created a rule banning transgender people from changing gender markers on their driver’s licenses.
Name: Tennessee Department of Safety and Homeland Security
Justification: the state’s Department of Safety and Homeland Security

SourcedStatement: The ACLU sued the agency for discrimination, claiming the rule was adopted illegally because it didn’t follow proper administrative procedure.
Name: ACLU
Justification: The ACLU

SourcedStatement: In January, a Florida agency announced it would no longer update a trans person’s driver’s license with their correct gender identity.
Name: Florida agency
Justification: a Florida agency

SourcedStatement: In August, at least one Texas agency, under directive from the state attorney general’s office, implemented a similar policy.
Name: Texas agency
Justification: at least one Texas agency, under directive from the state attorney general’s office

SourcedStatement: In Florida, which has emerged as a national epicenter of policies targeting LGBTQ+ people in recent years, the state’s Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles issued a new regulation barring residents from updating their gender identity on their drivers’ license.
Name: Florida Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles
Justification: the state’s Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles

SourcedStatement: The ACLU, which is tracking some of these laws and rules, has tried to prepare election workers on how to process trans voters who come into their polling sites.
Name: ACLU
Justification: The ACLU, which is tracking some of these laws and rules

SourcedStatement: VoteRiders is conducting year-round voter education.
Name: VoteRiders
Justification: VoteRiders

SourcedStatement: “There is a chilling effect,” said Lauren Kunis, CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification.
Name: Lauren Kunis
Title: CEO and executive director
Justification: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification

SourcedStatement: “There is an unsafe and intimidating environment around existing as trans in society, and definitely in being able to go to the polls safely and cast a ballot.”
Name: Lauren Kunis
Title: CEO and executive director
Justification: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification

SourcedStatement: “A lot is falling on poll workers to correctly enforce the law,” Kunis added.
Name: Lauren Kunis
Title: CEO and executive director
Justification: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification

SourcedStatement: “And I would argue that is less of a solid protection in states where anti-trans rhetoric is skyrocketing.”
Name: Lauren Kunis
Title: CEO and executive director
Justification: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification

SourcedStatement: He described Democratic vice presidential nominee Tim Walz recently as “very heavy into the transgender world.”
Name: Donald Trump
Title: former President
Justification: former President

SourcedStatement: “Trans votes count,” said Ankit Rastogi, director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality, which conducted the survey and will soon be known as Advocates for Trans Equality Education Fund.
Name: Ankit Rastogi
Title: director of research
Justification: director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality, which conducted the survey and will soon be known as Advocates for Trans Equality Education Fund

SourcedStatement: “I think the big takeaway is that our community is really trying to come out and make a difference through the democratic process.”
Name: Ankit Rastogi
Title: director of research
Justification: director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality, which conducted the survey and will soon be known as Advocates for Trans Equality Education Fund

SourcedStatement: Forcing a person to show identification that does not align with their gender identity could out them to people in their community, as Lucas Cameron-Vaughn, an attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee, explained.
Name: Lucas Cameron-Vaughn
Title: attorney
Justification: an attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee

SourcedStatement: “Trans people, just like everyone else, want to be able to travel, start new jobs, open bank accounts, enroll in school, vote — all of those things require some form of ID. And so when a state goes out of its way to enforce its message about its belief about sex and gender on a license, and transgender people then have to publicize that when they show other people, it creates a dangerous environment,” he said.
Name: Lucas Cameron-Vaughn
Title: attorney
Justification: an attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee

SourcedStatement: Last year, Tennessee Gov. Bill Lee, a Republican, signed a bill into law that defines sex as “determined by anatomy and genetics existing at the time of birth.”
Name: Bill Lee
Title: Gov.
Justification: Tennessee Gov., a Republican

SourcedStatement: “It’s a tactic that’s designed to splinter support for trans rights and suggest sort of who is harmed by protecting trans people — to frame that as cisgender women being the people harmed by protections for trans people,” said Rose Saxe, who is deputy project director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project.
Name: Rose Saxe
Title: deputy project director
Justification: deputy project director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project

SourcedStatement: “The states with the anti-trans laws are also the ones that are more likely to be passing anti-voter laws, full stop,” Kunis said.
Name: Lauren Kunis
Title: CEO and executive director
Justification: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification

SourcedStatement: To Quinn Diaz, a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida, the failure of most anti-LGBTQ+ bills introduced in this year’s legislative session showed that the tide in Florida is turning.
Name: Quinn Diaz
Title: public policy associate
Justification: a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida

SourcedStatement: But the new gender marker regulation signals yet another way that state agencies in Florida have overstepped their bounds and been “weaponized” to target transgender Floridians, they argued.
Name: Quinn Diaz
Title: public policy associate
Justification: a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida

SourcedStatement: “We saw it as a move to inflict maximum chaos and misunderstanding,” Diaz said.
Name: Quinn Diaz
Title: public policy associate
Justification: a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida

SourcedStatement: “And really to scare trans folks from even participating and getting the license if they needed to update it.”
Name: Quinn Diaz
Title: public policy associate
Justification: a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida

SourcedStatement: “With these laws in Florida, you’re forced to choose between living authentically and just not really participating in public life,” Diaz said.
Name: Quinn Diaz
Title: public policy associate
Justification: a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida

SourcedStatement: Diaz, who is transgender, moved to Florida from Massachusetts, where they had an “X” gender marker on their driver’s license.
Name: Quinn Diaz
Title: public policy associate
Justification: a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida; who is transgender

SourcedStatement: Because they didn’t have all the necessary documentation and weren’t established yet with a local provider when they transferred their license to Florida, they forfeited that marker and defaulted to a license with their sex assigned at birth.
Name: Quinn Diaz
Title: public policy associate
Justification: a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida; who is transgender

SourcedStatement: Diaz said they didn’t have any problems voting in person in the 2022 midterms, but they plan to vote by mail this November.
Name: Quinn Diaz
Title: public policy associate
Justification: a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida; who is transgender

SourcedStatement: “I can imagine that a lot of trans folks in Florida who might not have access … to an accurate and affirming ID might not want to engage in that process at all, especially in such a heightened political environment,” Diaz said.
Name: Quinn Diaz
Title: public policy associate
Justification: a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida; who is transgender

SourcedStatement: “Gender nonconforming people are already under such public scrutiny nationwide,” Diaz said.
Name: Quinn Diaz
Title: public policy associate
Justification: a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida; who is transgender

SourcedStatement: “That’s when you’re gonna see the convergence of those two elements. It really seems like it would only result in more discrimination, more discomfort for trans people, more interrogation and potentially just being turned away.”
Name: Quinn Diaz
Title: public policy associate
Justification: a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida; who is transgender

SourcedStatement: Hazel Krebs, a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law, felt the weight of that increased scrutiny as she cast her ballot in March.
Name: Hazel Krebs
Justification: a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law

SourcedStatement: Krebs wondered whether her identification — one that for weeks no longer reflected her gender identity — might impact her ability to vote.
Name: Hazel Krebs
Justification: a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law

SourcedStatement: She chatted with the election workers in the mostly empty precinct, then showed her ID.
Name: Hazel Krebs
Justification: a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law

SourcedStatement: She did her homework, learned that gender is not required information to vote and showed up ready to explain it.
Name: Hazel Krebs
Justification: a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law

SourcedStatement: But no one questioned her.
Name: Hazel Krebs
Justification: a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law

SourcedStatement: Krebs voted and was out of the polling site within minutes.
Name: Hazel Krebs
Justification: a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law

SourcedStatement: Still, she worries that, under the same circumstances, another trans person might have stayed home.
Name: Hazel Krebs
Justification: a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law

SourcedStatement: “They won’t stop me, but I can see how it would stop others,” she said.
Name: Hazel Krebs
Justification: a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law

SourcedStatement: “It is almost certainly stopping some people from showing up at the polls.”
Name: Hazel Krebs
Justification: a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law

SourcedStatement: While the driver’s license is the most ubiquitous form of identification in the United States’ car-centric society, Kunis wants to dispel the “common misconception” that it’s the only form of ID people can use to vote.
Name: Lauren Kunis
Title: CEO and executive director
Justification: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification

SourcedStatement: In addition to using passports as identification, Diaz said that Florida voters have the option to vote by mail, vote early in person and bring a friend or family member to the polls.
Name: Quinn Diaz
Title: public policy associate
Justification: a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida; who is transgender

SourcedStatement: “Our ability to participate in this democracy in Florida, it’s been on the line for a while,” Diaz said.
Name: Quinn Diaz
Title: public policy associate
Justification: a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida; who is transgender

SourcedStatement: Transgender people, they said, are being “forced to choose between participating in our greatest civic right or just sitting out because the state doesn’t see us for who we are.”
Name: Quinn Diaz
Title: public policy associate
Justification: a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida; who is transgender

SourcedStatement: “Something that’s very frustrating for us at VoteRiders is you will never be able to capture the number of people who do not feel safe voting, and who therefore stay home. And you also won’t be able to capture the people who are trans and show up to try and vote and are turned away.” Kunis said.
Name: Lauren Kunis
Title: CEO and executive director

SourcedStatement: “And we know that is happening, but it is difficult to quantify.”
Name: Lauren Kunis

Name: Lucas Cameron-Vaughn
Title: attorney
Justification: an attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee

SourcedStatement: “There are definitely the physical dangers, the dangers for harassment, discrimination — but also ultimately, voter suppression,” he said.
Name: Lucas Cameron-Vaughn
Title: attorney
Justification: an attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee

SourcedStatement: Trans people turned out to vote despite those policy roadblocks.

Justification: An analysis released in August of respondents to the 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey, widely seen as the most comprehensive study of binary and nonbinary transgender Americans; which conducted the survey and will soon be known as Advocates for Trans Equality Education Fund

Justification: according to the Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland, whose research was partially supported by VoteRiders
